{{about|the American Renaissance in literature|the use of the term in architecture and the arts|American Renaissance|the white supremacist periodical|American Renaissance (magazine)}}
The '''American Renaissance''' period in American literature ran from about 1830 to around the [[American Civil War|Civil War]].<ref name=":0">Boswell, Jeanetta. ''The American Renaissance and the Critics.'' Wakefield: Longwood Academic. {{ISBN|0-89341-599-5}}.</ref> A central term in [[American studies]], the American Renaissance was for a while considered synonymous with [[Romanticism#United States|American Romanticism]]<ref>Knight, Denise D. [https://books.google.com/books?id=z37rhqwq9mkC&pg=PR11&dq=%22American+Renaissance%22+%22romanticism%22&hl=en&ei=8qnZTI_kCoTHswaAt5XnBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22American%20Renaissance%22%20%22romanticism%22&f=false ''Writers of the American Renaissance: An A-to-Z Guide'']. Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press, 2003: XI.</ref> and was closely associated with [[Transcendentalism]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/ihas/icon/transcend.html|title=Retired Site - PBS Programs - PBS|author=|date=|work=PBS.org|access-date=April 23, 2017}}</ref>
==Overview== Scholar [[F. O. Matthiessen]] originated the phrase "American Renaissance" in his 1941 book ''American Renaissance: Art and Expression in the Age of Emerson and Whitman''. The thematic center of the American Renaissance was what Matthiessen called the "devotion" of all five of his writers to "the possibilities of democracy". He presented the American Renaissance texts as "literature for our democracy” and challenged the nation to repossess them.<ref>Lauter, Paul. [https://books.google.com/books?id=HGSf-VpoGIsC&pg=PA68&dq=American+renaissance+%22possibilities+of+democracy%22&hl=en&ei=_3P5TPrRLciSswa24LC-Aw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCIQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=American%20renaissance%20%22possibilities%20of%20democracy%22&f=false ''A Companion to American Literature and Culture'']. Chichester; Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell, 2010: 68 {{ISBN|0-631-20892-5}}</ref>
Often considered a movement centered in New England, the American Renaissance was inspired in part by a new focus on [[humanism]] as a way to move from [[Calvinism]].<ref>Howe, Daniel Walker. ''What Hath God Wrought? The Transformation of America, 1815–1848''. New York: Oxford University Press, 2007: 615. {{ISBN|978-0-19-507894-7}}</ref> Literary nationalists at this time were calling for a movement that would develop a unique American literary style to distinguish American literature from British literature.<ref name=":0" /> Walter Channing in a November 1815 issue of the ''[[North American Review]]'' called for the people to form "a literature of our own", which was later echoed by other literary critics.<ref name=":2" /> Following this call, there was a wave of literary nationalism in America for much of the 1820s that saw writers such as [[Washington Irving]], [[William Cullen Bryant]], and [[James Fenimore Cooper]] become the identity of writers worthy of American literature. From this wave of literary nationalism the American Renaissance can be seen as being born.<ref name=":2" />
==Criticisms == There are many criticisms associated with the American Renaissance, and some critics question if it ever actually took place. One of the most prominent criticisms is that authors during this period are seen as simply taking styles and ideas from past movements and culture and reforming them into new, contemporary works.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Beneath the American Renaissance|last = Reynolds|first = David|publisher = Alfred A. Knopf, Inc.|year = 1988|isbn = 9780394544489|location = New York|pages = }}</ref>
Some critics say that authors fail to address major political issues during this period, such as slavery, even as they had large influence on the writing of the time.<ref name=":2" /> There is also criticism that women authors and women's issues were generally left out of discussion and publication.<ref name=":1" />
The notion of an American Renaissance has been criticized for overemphasizing a small number of white male writers and artifacts of high culture.<ref>Buell, Lawrence. [https://books.google.com/books?id=nPgRcKfZebwC&pg=PA145&dq=%22american+renaissance%22+%22white+male+writers%22&hl=en&ei=y_TWTOLSGpHDswa3y9iDCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22american%20renaissance%22%20%22white%20male%20writers%22&f=false ''Emerson'']. Cambridge and London: Harvard University Press, 2003: 145.</ref> William E. Cain noted the "extreme white male formation" of Matthiessen's list of authors and stated that by "devoting hundreds of pages of analysis and celebration to five white male authors, Matthiessen unwittingly prefigured in his book what later readers would dispute and labor to correct."<ref>Cain, William E. [https://books.google.com/books?id=G1TowJSnxrgC&pg=PA168&dq=%22american+renaissance%22+%22male+authors%22&hl=en&ei=XffWTOTkGY7Eswah18SICA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22american%20renaissance%22%20%22male%20authors%22&f=false ''F.O. Matthiessen and the Politics of Criticism'']. Madison: University of Wisconsin Press, 1988: 168.</ref>
Some critics argue that literature written by women during this period was not as popular as first thought, and that it took a distant second place in popularity to works written by men. Matthiessen and other scholars are even known to exclude women and minority authors, especially African Americans.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = The Norton Anthology of American Literature|last = Baym|publisher = W.W. Norton & Company|year = |isbn = 0393918858|location = New York|pages = 445–463|chapter = American Literature 1820-1865|last2 = Levine}}</ref> Critics also argue that there is no separate style or genre, such as sentimental-domestic fiction, distinguished by gender.<ref name=":1" /> However, other critics point out that the most read authors of the time were women, such as [[Harriet Beecher Stowe]] and [[Fanny Fern]] <ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url = http://dcc.newberry.org/collections/the-american-renaissance-in-context|title = The American Renaissance in Context|date = 2014|access-date = November 10, 2015|website = |publisher = |last = Howe|first = Lawrence|last2 = Layson|first2 = Hana}}</ref> and criticize Matthiessen for not including women in the original canon.<ref name=":3" />
The demographic exclusivity of the American Renaissance began eroding among scholars toward the end of the twentieth century. They have included [[Emily Dickinson]] in the canon; she started writing poetry in the late 1850s. [[Harriet Beecher Stowe]]’s ''[[Uncle Tom’s Cabin]]'' (1852) rose to a prominent reputation in the late 1970s. African-American literature, including [[slave narratives]] by such masters as [[Frederick Douglass]], and early novels by [[William Wells Brown]], has gained increasing recognition.<ref>Jarrett, Gene Andrew. [https://books.google.com/books?id=jii8XeIKtA0C&pg=PA103&dq=%22american+renaissance%22+%22white+male+authors%22&hl=en&ei=MPbWTPrINM7ysgbPs7DVCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22american%20renaissance%22%20%22white%20male%20authors%22&f=false ''A Companion to African American Literature'']. Chichester, U.K.; Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell, 2010: 103.</ref>
==Notable authors== Most often associated with the American Renaissance movement are [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]]'s ''[[Representative Men]]'' and ''[[Self-Reliance]]'', [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]]'s ''[[The Scarlet Letter]]'' and ''[[The House of Seven Gables]]'', [[Herman Melville]]'s ''[[Moby-Dick]]'', [[Henry David Thoreau]]'s ''[[Walden]]'', and [[Walt Whitman]]'s'' [[Leaves of Grass]]''. Most of the main writers associated with the American Renaissance were actually rather unknown during this time and had small followings.<ref name=":2" />
Other authors were later added to this list and found to have contributed to this movement. These include: [[Edgar Allan Poe]], [[Harriet Beecher Stowe]], [[Emily Dickinson]], [[Frederick Douglass]], [[William Wells Brown]], [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow]], and [[John Greenleaf Whittier]] among others.<ref name=":0" />

'''[[Art competitions at the Summer Olympics|Art competitions]]''' were held as part of the '''[[1936 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]. Medals were awarded in five categories ([[architecture]], [[literature]], [[music]], [[painting]], and [[sculpture]]), for works inspired by sport-related themes. The art exhibition was held in a hall of the [[Messe Berlin|Berlin Exhibition]] from July 15 to August 16, and displayed 667 works of art from 22 different countries. Additionally, the literature competition attracted 40 entries from 12 countries, and the music competition had 33 entries from 9 countries.{{cite book |last=Diem |first=Carl |title=XIth Olympic Games, Berlin 1936 Official Report |publisher=Wilhelm Limpert |location=Berlin |year=1937 |pages=1106–1123 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1936/1936v2sum.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-03-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080406153656/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1936/1936v2sum.pdf| archivedate= 6 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} The art competitions at the 1936 Games were similar to the 1928 and 1932 Games, with medals being awarded in multiple subcategories for each of the five artistic categories.{{cite web |title=Olympic Art Competition 1936 Berlin |work=Olympic Games Museum |author=Wagner, Juergen |url=http://olympic-museum.de/art/1936.htm |accessdate=2008-03-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080501132445/http://www.olympic-museum.de/art/1936.htm| archivedate= 1 May 2008 | deadurl= no}} The judges declined to award any medals for three subcategories, and no gold medals for another three subcategories. [[Image:Guidatore di sulky e Saltatore.JPG|thumb|300px|[[Farpi Vignoli]] won a gold medal in ''Statues'' for his "Sulky Driver" (left).]] Art competitions were part of the Olympic program from 1912 to 1948.{{cite journal |title=In Search of the Lost Champions of the Olympic Art Contests |last=Kramer |first=Bernhard |journal=Journal of Olympic History |volume=12 |issue=2 |date=May 2004 |pages=29–34 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/JOH/JOHv12n2/johv12n2m.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-03-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080410082301/http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/JOH/JOHv12n2/johv12n2m.pdf| archivedate= 10 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} At a meeting of the [[International Olympic Committee]] in 1949, it was decided to hold art ''exhibitions'' instead, as it was judged illogical to permit professionals to compete in the art competitions but only amateurs were permitted to compete in sporting events.{{cite journal |title=Report on Art Exhibitions |last=Bolanaki |first=A. |journal=Bulletin du Comité International Olympique |issue=27 |date=June 1951 |page=34 |publisher=International Olympic Committee |location=Lausanne |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/OlympicInformationCenter/OlympicReview/1951/BDCE27/BDCE27l.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-03-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080410082302/http://www.la84foundation.org/OlympicInformationCenter/OlympicReview/1951/BDCE27/BDCE27l.pdf| archivedate= 10 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} Since 1952, a non-competitive art and cultural festival has been associated with each Games. ==Architecture== {| style="width:100%" {{MedalistTable|type=Category|width=27%|labelwidth=19%}} |- |Architectural design |{{flagathlete|[[Hermann Kutschera]]|AUT}}

[[File:DasKapitalZwo.jpg|thumb|''Das Kapital, Volume II'']] {{Italic title}} '''''Capital, Volume II: The Process of Circulation of Capital''''' is the second of three volumes of ''[[Capital: Critique of Political Economy]]''. It was prepared by [[Friedrich Engels]] from notes left by [[Karl Marx]] and published in 1885.
==Contents== Volume II is divided into three parts:<ref>{{cite book|title=Capital Vol2.|isbn=0-7178-0483-6|last=Engels|first=Friedrich|publisher=International Publishers Co, Inc.|year=1967}}</ref>
# The Metamorphoses of Capital and Their Circuits # The Turnover of Capital # The [[reproduction (economics)|Reproduction]] and Circulation of the Aggregate Social Capital
In this book, the main ideas behind the marketplace are to be found: how value and surplus-value are realized. Its dramatis personae, not so much the worker and the industrialist (as in Volume I), but rather the money owner (and money lender), the wholesale merchant, the trader and the entrepreneur or 'functioning capitalist.' Moreover, workers appear in Volume II, essentially as buyers of consumer goods and, therefore, as sellers of the commodity [[labour power]], rather than producers of value and [[surplus-value]] (although, this latter quality, established in Volume I, remains the solid foundation on which the whole of the unfolding analysis is based).
Marx wrote in a letter sent to Engels on 30 April 1868: 'In Book 1. . . we content ourselves with the assumption that if in the self-expansion process £100 becomes £110, the latter will find ''already in existence in the market'' the elements into which it will change once more. But now we investigate the conditions under which these elements are found at hand, namely the social intertwining of the different capitals, of the component parts of capital and of revenue (= s).' This intertwining, conceived as a movement of commodities and of money, enabled Marx to work out at least the essential elements, if not the definitive form of a coherent theory of the trade cycle, based upon the inevitability of periodic disequilibrium between supply and demand under the [[capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist mode of production]] (Mandel, 1978, Intro to Vol. II of ''Capital'').
Part 3 is the point of departure for the topic of [[capital accumulation]], which was given its Marxist treatment later in detail by, among others, [[Rosa Luxemburg]].

{{hatnote|This article is about the concept. For the book by Mark Fisher, see [[Capitalist Realism: Is There No Alternative?]]}} {{Infobox art movement | name = Capitalist realism | image = | image_size = | caption = | yearsactive = From [[Pop Art]] in the 1950s and 1960s to the commodity art of the 1980s and 1990s | country = Germany | majorfigures = [[Mark Fisher (theorist)|Mark Fisher]], [[Michael Schudson]], [[Gerhard Richter]], [[Sigmar Polke]], [[Wolf Vostell]], and Konrad Lueg | influences = | influenced = }} The term "'''capitalist realism'''" has been used, particularly in [[Germany]], to describe commodity-based art, from [[Pop Art]] in the 1950s and 1960s to the commodity art of the 1980s and 1990s.Gibbons, p.53 Alternatively, it has been used to describe the ideological-aesthetic aspect of contemporary [[corporate capitalism]] in the West. When used in this way, it is a play on the term "[[socialist realism]]". ==In art== Although attested earlier,E.g. by [[Abraham Polonsky]] of [[Edward Dmytryk|Edward Dmytryk's]] ''[[The Caine Mutiny (film)|The Caine Mutiny]]'': William Pechter and Abraham Polonsky, 'Abraham Polonsky and "Force of Evil"', ''Film Quarterly'', 15.3 [Special Issue on Hollywood] (Spring, 1962), 47-54 (p. 53); https://www.jstor.org/stable/1210628. the phrase "capitalist realism" was first used in the title of the 1963 [[art exhibition]] in [[Düsseldorf, Germany|Düsseldorf]], ''Demonstration for Capitalist Realism'', which featured the work of [[Gerhard Richter]], [[Sigmar Polke]], [[Wolf Vostell]], and [[:de:Konrad Fischer (Maler)|Konrad Lueg]].Honour, Hugh. ''A World History of Art'', Laurence King Publishing, p847. {{ISBN|1-85669-451-8}} The exhibition's participants focused upon depictions of Germany's growing consumer culture and media-saturated society with strategies, in part, influenced by those of their American Pop{{cite web | url=http://observer.com/2014/07/living-with-pop-a-reproduction-of-capitalist-realism-at-artists-space/ | title=Living With Pop: A Reproduction of Capitalist Realism' at Artists Space | publisher=The New York Observer | date=23 July 2014 | accessdate=20 November 2014 | author=Pollack, Maika | quote=It was a reaction to Pop from a postwar Germany divided between East and West.}} counterparts. The recent rise in [[Pop art|Pop Art]] in German culture was coupled by a fascination with America, which served as a stimulation for the piece. They were inspired primarily by the iconography depicted in newspapers and magazines. ==Sigmar Polke== {{main|Sigmar Polke}} Capitalist realism is a German art movement co-founded in 1963 by artist [[Sigmar Polke]].{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/12/AR2010061203694.html | title=German artist Sigmar Polke, creator of 'Higher Beings Command,' dies at 69 | publisher=The Washington Post | date=13 June 2010 | accessdate=17 November 2014 | author=Schudel, Matt | quote=In the 1960s, Mr. Polke was at the vanguard of a German artistic movement called capitalist realism, along with fellow painter Gerhard Richter -- who later expressed reservations about his colleague's work, saying "he refuses to accept any borders, any limits."}} Polke embraced the advertising and publicity commonly found in the popular press in renderings of everyday consumer items. Often ironic and with critical overtones of society and politics the Capitalist Realism movement is considered more explicitly political than conventional Pop Art.Crow, Thomas. ''The Rise of the Sixties: American and European Art in the age of Dissent'' {{ISBN|1856694267}} ==Michael Schudson== {{main|Michael Schudson}} In the mid-1980s, [[Michael Schudson]] used the term "capitalist realism" to describe mainstream practices in advertising.Gibbons, p.55 Chapter seven of Schudson's ''Advertising: The Uneasy Persuasion'' compares the messages and appeals of advertising to those found in the Socialist Realism of the [[Soviet Union]].Michael Schudson, 'Advertising as Capitalist Realism', in ''Advertising, The Uneasy Persuasion: Its Dubious Impact on American Society'' (New York: Basic Books, 1984), pp. 209-33 (repr. in '' Advertising & Society Review'', vol. 1, issue 1 (2000). In his account, the realism of advertising promotes a way of life based on private consumption, rather than social, public achievement.Richards, Harry; MacRury, Isin; Botterill, Jackie. ''The Dynamics of Advertising'', Routledge, 2000, p99. {{ISBN|90-5823-085-6}} ==Mark Fisher== {{main|Capitalist Realism: Is There No Alternative?}} The term next appeared in 2009 with the publication of Mark Fisher's book ''[[Capitalist Realism: Is There No Alternative?]]''Mark Fisher, ''Capitalist Realism: Is There No Alternative?'' (Winchester, UK; Washington [D.C.]: Zero, 2009); {{ISBN|978-1-84694-317-1}} (pbk.); 1846943175 (pbk.). Fisher argues that the term "capitalist realism" best describes the current global political situation, which lacks visible alternatives to the capitalist system which became dominant following the fall of the [[Soviet Union]]. His argument is a response to, and critique of, [[neo-liberalism]] and new forms of government which apply the logic of [[capitalism]] and the market to all aspects of governance. His ideology refers to a perceived "widespread sense that not only is capitalism the only viable political and economic system, but also that it is now impossible even to imagine a coherent alternative to it". {{Cite book|title=Capitalist Realism: Is There No Alternative?|last=Fisher|first=Mark|publisher=Zero Books|year=2010|isbn=|location=Winchester, UK|pages=2}} As a philosophical concept, capitalist realism is influenced by the [[Althusserian]] conception of ideology.{{Cite book|title=Capitalist Realism: Is There No Alternative?|last=Fisher|first=Mark|publisher=Zero Books|year=2009|isbn=978-1846943171|location=|pages=}} Fisher proposes that within a capitalist framework there is no space to conceive of alternative forms of social structures, adding that younger generations are not even concerned with recognizing alternatives.{{Cite book|title=Capitalist Realism. Is There No Alternative?|last=Fisher|first=Mark|publisher=O Books|year=2009|isbn=9781846943171|location=|pages=8|quote=|via=}} He proposes that the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|2008 financial crisis]] compounded this position. Rather than catalyzing a desire to seek alternatives for the existing model, the crisis reinforced the notion that modifications must be made within the existing system. The crash confirmed within the populace the necessity of capitalism rather than shake it loose from its foundations.
''Capitalist realism as I understand it cannot be confined to art or to the quasi-propagandistic way in which advertising functions. It is more like a pervasive atmosphere, conditioning not only the production of culture but also the regulation of work and education, and acting as a kind of invisible barrier constraining thought and action.''Mark Fisher, ''Capitalist Realism: Is there no Alternative?'' (Winchester, UK; Washington [D.C.]: Zero, 2009).
Fisher argues that capitalist realism has propagated a 'business [[ontology]]' which concludes that everything should be run as a business including education and healthcare.Mark Fisher, ''Capitalist Realism: Is There No Alternative?'' (Winchester, UK; Washington [D.C.]: Zero, 2009, pg15). Following the publication of Fisher's work, the term has been picked up by other literary critics.Prominently Mark Fisher and Jeremy Gilbert, 'Capitalist Realism and Neoliberal Hegemony: A Dialogue', ''New Formations'', 80--81 (2013), 89--101 DOI:10.3898/NEWF.80/81.05.2013; ''Reading Capitalist Realism'', ed. by Alison Shonkwiler and Leigh Claire La Berge (Iowa City: University of Iowa Press, 2014). ==See also== * [[Real capital]] * [[Socialist realism]] * [[Social realism]] ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== * Caldwell, John. ''Sigmar Polke'', (San Francisco:San Francisco Museum of Modern Art) 1990, p 9 * Gibbons, Joan. ''Art And Advertising''. I.B.Tauris, {{ISBN|1-85043-586-3}} * "Capitalist Realism." Artsy. N.p., n.d. {{For|other uses of Demerara|Demerara (disambiguation)}} [[File:FRANCIA GREAT HOUSE BARBADOS.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Francia Great House]], Barbados has Demerara windows.]] '''Demerara windows''' were built primarily into 18th- and 19th-century [[Colonial architecture]]-styled buildings{{efn|It was also used into the 20th century, such as Hayes Court (1910), one of the [[Magnificent Seven Houses]] in [[Trinidad and Tobago]]<ref>{{cite web | author=National Trust of Trinidad and Tobago| url=http://nationaltrust.tt/location/hayes-court/ | title=Hayes Court | website=National Trust of Trinidad and Tobago | date=January 18, 2016 |accessdate=November 21, 2016}}</ref> and the [[Francia Great House]] (late 19th century or early 20th century).}} to cool homes in hot climates, such as [[Guyana]], before the invention of [[air conditioning]]. The [[window]] design includes perforated sides and [[Louvre (window)|louvre]]s to block direct sunlight. They are shuttered [[sash windows]] with the shutter hinged at the top so it could be propped open, sloping outward.<ref name="Westmas" /><ref name="Murtland" /> They were generally propped open with a stick.<ref name="Winer2009">{{cite book|author=Lise Winer|title=Dictionary of the English/Creole of Trinidad & Tobago: On Historical Principles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_n82hsbDJBMC&pg=PA290|date=January 16, 2009|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP|isbn=978-0-7735-7607-0|page=290}}</ref> At the window sill, a container of ice, water, or a potted plant helps cool warm air as it passes through the window into the building. The windows are generally fitted in the upper floors. Initially, this type of window was just used in the homes of the wealthy, but spread over time to the homes of other classes of people.<ref name="Westmas" /><ref name="Murtland">{{Cite news |url=https://www.kaieteurnewsonline.com/2017/04/23/the-demerara-window-the-colonial-ac/ |title=The Demerara Window – the Colonial ‘AC’ |date=April 23, 2017 |work=Kaieteur News |first=Murtland |last=Haley|access-date=June 2, 2018}}</ref>
They were generally made of pine because the wood was less likely to move than native timbers in heat and humidity. It was generally made with twelve panes, which is a [[Georgian architecture|Georgian-style architectural]] detail.<ref name="Westmas">{{Cite news |url=https://www.stabroeknews.com/2010/guyana-review/05/31/architecture/ |title=Architecture - Building Under the Sun |last=Rory |first=Westmas |date=May 31, 2010 |work=Stabroek News |access-date=June 2, 2018}}</ref>
In other parts of the Caribbean, particularly the British colonies and territories such as [[Grenada]],<ref name="Noble2009">{{cite book|author=Allen Noble|title=Traditional Buildings: A Global Survey of Structural Forms and Cultural Functions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MYkAAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA206|date=18 September 2009|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-0-85771-745-0|pages=206–}}</ref> the name came to be generally applied to a window that opens outwards from hinges at the top.<ref name="Noble2009">{{cite book|author=Allen Noble|title=Traditional Buildings: A Global Survey of Structural Forms and Cultural Functions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MYkAAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA206|date=18 September 2009|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-0-85771-745-0|pages=206–}}</ref>

Weekly|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref>. Dirty Looks began regular Los Angeles programming in January 2015. [[File:Royal Standard of the Netherlands.svg|thumb|260px|Royal Standard of the Netherlands.]] The '''flags of the Dutch royal family''' are a set of flags used to identify a member of the royal family. The current system of flags for the Dutch monarch, princes, and princesses was introduced in 1908. == Background == The current system of personal flags for the monarch and other members of the royal family was introduced in 1908. In 1907, minor modifications were introduced to the Dutch coat of arms; likewise, a new flag for the Dutch monarch was introduced the following year. These flags are designed by the High Council of Nobility (who are also responsible for heraldry of the royal family) and are granted by royal decree. Like their coats of arms, these flags are usually shared among siblings. The flags follow a similar pattern and, although not [[banner of arms|banners of arms]], are heavily influenced by heraldry. Flags of those born into the royal family feature a Nassau-blue cross on an orange field, while the colours are reversed for those who marry into the family. Males have near-square flags while those of females are swallowtailed. Elements of an individual's family coat of arms are also incorporated into the flags. == Use == The flags are used to mark the presence of an individual in certain buildings, when on vehicles (e.g. a car or ship), or in an army unit. The flag of the monarch is flown above [[Huis ten Bosch Palace]] in [[The Hague]] (the king's private residence) and above [[Noordeinde Palace]] in The Hague (the king's official residence) when the monarch is in the Netherlands, but not necessarily when he is actually resident. Besides these two residences, the royal standard is flown above other palaces, castles or estates where and when the King is actually staying. The flags are never flown at half-mast; during a period of mourning, a black [[pennon]] is affixed to the flagpole flying the flag.{{cite web|title=Personal flags|url=https://www.royal-house.nl/topics/flags/personal-flags|website=www.royal-house.nl|accessdate=25 August 2017}} == Royal standard == The '''royal flag''' ({{lang-nl|koninklijke vlag}}), or the '''royal standard''' of the [[Netherlands]], is the official flag of the [[Monarchy of the Netherlands|Dutch monarch]]. This flag is a non-personal distinctive flag and is not changed from reign to reign. The current flag, introduced in 1908, is a square [[orange (colour)|orange]] flag, divided in four quarters by a nassau-blue [[cross]]. These colours refer to the principality of [[Principality of Orange|Orange]] (in [[France]]) and the principality of [[Duchy of Nassau|Nassau]] (in [[Germany]]) from which the present royal family originates. In the centre of the flag is the lesser [[Coat of arms of the Netherlands|coat of arms of the Kingdom]] (which originates as a composite of features taken from the arms of the [[house of Nassau]] and the [[Dutch Republic Lion|arms of the Dutch republic]]) surmounted by a [[Crown (headgear)|royal crown]] and surrounded by the insignia of the Grand Cross of the [[Military William Order]]. Each quarter shows a bugle-horn which originates in arms of the principality of Orange. Image:Arms of the Principality of Orange.svg| [[Principality of Orange]] Image:Arms of Nassau.svg| [[House of Nassau]] Image:Arms of the Kingdom of the Netherlands.svg| [[Coat of arms of the Netherlands|Netherlands]] Upon the accession of King [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands|Willem-Alexander]] in 2013, the monarch's flag was slightly modified: Instead of a rosette, a bow is placed in the ribbon of the Military William Order. Furthermore, the tassels on the horns now both hang down. The adjustments were applied on 30 April 2013 immediately after Willem-Alexander taking office. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- ! style="width:120px;"| Flag ! style="width:180px;"| Usage ! colspan=2 | Notes |- |align=center| [[Image:Royal Standard of the Netherlands (1908–2013).svg|100px|border]] |align=center| 1908–2013 | The flag introduced in 1908 was modified slightly in 2013, on the accession of King [[Willem-Alexander]]. | style="width:190px;" align=center| [[Image:Changes in the Royal Standard of the Netherlands.gif|180px|border]] |- |align=center| [[Image:Royal Standard of the Netherlands (1815–1908).svg|100px|border]] |align=center| 1815–1908 | colspan=2 | Before 1908, the flag used by the monarch was a rectangular flag with the colours of the [[Flag of the Netherlands|national flag]]. Within the centre white band was the [[Coat of arms of the Netherlands#History and origin of the coat of arms|coat of arms as it appeared during the time]] (without the mantle). |} ==Princes== The flag of a Dutch prince is rectangular in shape and of proportions 5:6. Flags of princes born into the royal family consist of a Nassau-blue cross on an orange field. Instead of the hunting horn of Orange in the upper right and the lower left quarters found in the monarch's flag, these are replaced with figures obtained from the coat of arms of the family of the prince's parent who married into the royal family. Unlike the monarch's flag, the coat of arms of the kingdom is not surrounded by the insignia of the Great Cross of the Military Order of Guillaume, but is placed within an orange circle which replaces the center of the cross. {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !width="10%"|Standard !width="25%"|Member of the Royal Family !width="65%"|Description |- | [[File:Standard of a Prince of the Netherlands (sons of Beatrix).svg|100px|border]] |

The arms of the Netherlands without the insignia of the Order of Willem is within an orange circle. |- |[[File:Standard of the Princes of the Nethelands (Sons of Princess Margriet ).png|100px|border]] |

Flags of princesses born into the royal family consist of a Nassau-blue cross on an orange field while the flags of princesses by marriage are reversed. Unlike the flags for princes, the right side of the flag is devoid of the hunting horn of Orange and personal figure. However, the left portion of a princesse's flag contains the usual hunting horn of Orange and personal figure (obtained from the coat of arms of the family of the princess's parent who married into the royal family) in the upper and lower left quarters of the flag respectively. Unlike the monarch's flag, the coat of arms of the kingdom is not surrounded by the insignia of the Great Cross of the Military Order of Guillaume, but is placed either within an orange circle which replaces the center of a blue cross, or at the centre of an orange cross. {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !width="10%"|Standard !width="25%"|Member of the Royal Family !width="65%"|Description |- |[[File:Standard of Princess Laurentien of the Netherlands.png|100px]] |

(Wife of Prince Constantijn)

The arms of the Netherlands without the insignia of the Order of Willem is in the cross. |- |[[File:Standard of the Princesses of the Netherlands (Daughters of Queen Juliana).png|100px]] |

| The former standard for Dutch princesses was a swallowtailed flag, with the colours of the historical royal standard with the royal coat of arms in an orange rectangle at the central band. |- |} ==Consorts== In general, the standard of a prince consort of the Netherlands is a rectangular flag with proportions 5:6 with the colours of the royal standard (i.e. the orange field and blue cross) reversed. The upper left and lower right quarters bear the lion from the Dutch coat of arms (holding arrows in one hand and brandishing a sword on the other) while the other two quarters have a personal figure taken from their personal coat of arms. In general, the standard of a queen consort, or the wife of a prince of the Netherlands, is a flag in the form of a swallow tail. The two right quarters are empty, the upper left corner bears the orange horn taken from the arms of the Principality of Orange and the lower left quarter has a personal figure, taken from their personal coat of arms. In both cases, the coat of arms of the kingdom is at the center of the cross. {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !width="10%"|Standard !width="25%"|Person !width="65%"|Description !Family arms |- |[[File:Royal Standard of Máxima of Orange-Nassau.svg|100px]] |

Hunter | discipline = [[Art History]] and [[Architecture]] | abbreviation = Grey Room | publisher = [[MIT Press]] | country = United States | frequency = Quarterly | history = 2000-present | openaccess = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.mitpressjournals.org/loi/grey | link1 = http://www.mitpressjournals.org/toc/grey/current | link1-name = Online access | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = 15263819 | OCLC = 47027776 | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 1526-3819 | eISSN = 1536-0105 }} '''''Grey Room''''' is a [[peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] published quarterly, in print and online, by the [[MIT Press]]. Founded in 2000, it includes work in the fields of [[architecture]], [[art]], [[Media (communication)|media]], and [[politics]]. To date it has featured contributions by such prominent historians and theorists as [[Yve-Alain Bois]], [[Judith Butler]], [[Georges Canguilhem]], [[Hubert Damisch]], [[Friedrich Kittler]], [[Chantal Mouffe]], [[Antonio Negri]], [[Paolo Virno]], [[Paul Virilio]], and [[Samuel Weber]].
Beginning with issue #51, the composition of the editorial board changed. Founding editors Branden Joseph, [[Reinhold Martin]], and Felicity Scott, and editors Karen Beckman and Tom McDonough, resigned from the editorial board after issue #50 and assumed roles on the advisory board of the journal. Zeynep Çelik Alexander, Lucia Allais, Eric de Bruyn, Gabriella Coleman (since resigned from the editorial board), Noam M. Elcott, John Harwood, Byron Hamann, and Matthew C. Hunter have served as editors since.

'''Katherine Milhous''' (1894–1977) was an [[American people |American]] artist, illustrator, and writer. She is known best as the author and illustrator of ''[[The Egg Tree]]'', which won the 1951 [[Caldecott Medal]] for U.S. picture book illustration. Born into a [[Quaker]] family active in the [[printing]] industry in Philadelphia, Milhous is also known for her graphic designs for the [[Works Progress Administration]](WPA). Her work has been exhibited at the [[1939 New York World's Fair]] and at the [[Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts]].
==Life== Katherine Milhous was born November 27, 1894, to Osborn and Katherine Daly Milhous of Philadelphia, Quakers who made their living as printers. When she was young they moved to [[Pitman, New Jersey]], a small camp-meeting town.<ref>{{cite web | title =Our Town | work = Pittman, NJ | url = http://members.tripod.com/~passinthru_2/pitman.htm| accessdate = 2012-04-26}}</ref> She returned to Philadelphia to attend the [[Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts]] and the [[University of the Arts (Philadelphia)|Pennsylvania Museum School of Industrial Art]].<ref name=WDL1>{{cite web|title=Poster of an Amish Family, Pennsylvania|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/9569/|work=Work Projects Administration Poster Collection|publisher=[[World Digital Library]]|accessdate=2 January 2014}}</ref> Milhous helped support her schooling by illustrating magazines. In 1934, while at the Academy of Fine Arts, she won the Cresson Traveling Fellowship, which allowed her to study overseas. She then returned to Philadelphia where, for forty years, she shared a studio with friend and fellow-artist Frances Lichten.<ref name=freelibrary>{{cite web | title = Katherine Milhous and Frances Lichten Papers| work = Free Library of Philadelphia | url = http://libwww.freelibrary.org/ead/view.cfm?name=Milhous | accessdate = 2012-04-26}}</ref>
From 1935 to 1940 Milhous was a supervisor for the Philadelphia [[Federal Art Project]] (FAP), a branch of the [[Works Progress Administration]].<ref name=WDL1/> Among her duties was the creation of posters promoting Pennsylvania. She incorporated familiar [[Pennsylvania Dutch]] designs into her posters.<ref>{{cite web | title =Purchase Posters | work = Kate Milhous | url =http://postersforthepeople.com/catalogsearch/result/?q=kate+milhous&x=0&y=0 |accessdate = 2012-04-26}}</ref> [[Alice Dalgliesh]], head of the Children's Book division of [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Charles Scribner's & Sons]], saw Milhous' posters during an exhibition in an FAP gallery, and hired her as a staff designer. Milhous co-wrote and illustrated several books with Dalgliesh, who was also an award-winning children's writer. She also illustrated for others, as well as writing and illustrating her own books.<ref name=freelibrary/>
Milhous was a member of the [[AIGA|American Institute of Graphic Arts]]. She died in Philadelphia on December 5, 1977. Her papers are held in the University of Minnesota [[University of Minnesota Libraries#Library buildings and collections | Children's Literature Research Collection]]<ref>{{cite web | title =Katherine Milhous Collection | work = University of Minnesota| url = http://special.lib.umn.edu/findaid/xml/CLRC-58.xml| accessdate = 2012-04-26}}</ref> and the [[Free Library of Philadelphia]].<ref name=freelibrary/>
==Critical reception== Milhous' books were generally well received by reviewers, both for their writing and their illustrations. ''Appalonia's Valentine'' was called "distinguished… original and beautiful".<ref>{{cite web | title =Books for Young People | work = The Saturday Review | url = http://www.unz.org/Pub/SaturdayRev-1954feb13-00052| accessdate = 2012-04-27}}</ref> On ''Patrick and the Golden Slippers'', about Philadelphia's Mummers' Parade, the same magazine wrote "This is a picture book of enduring value to young Americans."<ref>{{cite web | title =Autumn Color | work = The Saturday Review | url = http://www.unz.org/Pub/SaturdayRev-1951oct20-00038 | accessdate = 2012-04-27}}</ref> In her Caldecott Medal-winning ''The Egg Tree'', "Her use of bright [[tempera]] paints brought to life the bold borders and vibrant pages of the book."<ref>{{cite web | title =Biography of Katherine Milhous| work = by Miranda Orso | url = http://pabook.libraries.psu.edu/palitmap/bios/Milhous__Katherine.html | accessdate = 2012-04-27}}</ref>

{{About||the American television film|Killing Jesus (2015 film)|the Colombian film|Killing Jesus (2017 film)}} {{Infobox book | name = Killing Jesus | image = Killing Jesus cover.jpg | caption = | author = [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] and [[Martin Dugard (author)|Martin Dugard]] | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | subject = [[Crucifixion of Jesus]] | genre = | publisher = Henry Holt and Co. | pub_date = September 24, 2013 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Hardcover | pages = 304 | isbn = 978-0805098549 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = [[Killing Lincoln]] | followed_by = [[Killing Patton]] }} '''''Killing Jesus: A History''''' is a 2013 book by [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] and [[Martin Dugard (author)|Martin Dugard]] about the [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament|life]] and [[crucifixion of Jesus]], referred to in the book as [[Jesus|Jesus of Nazareth]]. It is the follow-up to ''[[Killing Kennedy]]'' and ''[[Killing Lincoln]]''. ''Killing Jesus'' was released September 24, 2013<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/killing-jesus-bill-oreilly/1114668114?ean=9780805098549 |title=Killing Jesus: A History |author=Bill O'Reilly |isbn=9780805098549|publisher=[[Barnes & Noble]]}}</ref> through [[Henry Holt and Company]]. The book was a commercial success, debuting at #1 on ''[[The New York Times]]'' [[The New York Times Non-Fiction Best Sellers of 2013|bestseller list]] and remaining on the list for 52 weeks. Popular reviews of the book were mixed, with both Christian and non-Christian reviewers faulting the book for its tedious writing and its claims of historical objectivity. Scholars and historians have extensively criticized the book for its inaccurate, politically-motivated portrayal of Jesus as a "[[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] Son of God", its uncritical approach to [[primary source]]s, its omission of some of Jesus' teachings, and its oversimplified, sensationalist portrayal of history. Like both its predecessors, the book was adapted into a [[Killing Jesus (miniseries)|television miniseries with the same name]] for [[National Geographic Channel]].
==Writing and research== According to ''[[The Washington Times]]'', while writing ''Killing Jesus'', O'Reilly and Dugard found that sources were far less plentiful than for the previous books in their ''Killing...'' series.<ref name="Vernon2013">{{cite news |last1=Vernon |first1=Wes |title=BOOK REVIEW: 'Killing Jesus' |url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/sep/25/book-review-killing-jesus/ |accessdate=8 June 2018 |work=The Washington Times |publisher=The Washington Times, LLC |date=25 September 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref> They stated that the Internet was "a treasure",<ref name="Vernon2013"/> but complained that the information on various websites was "contradictory",<ref name="Vernon2013"/> that "hearsay was often quoted as truth",<ref name="Vernon2013"/> and that information from one website was frequently shown to be unreliable when checked against information from more reliable sources.<ref name="Vernon2013"/> Bill O'Reilly stated that he believes the book was [[divine inspiration|inspired]] by the [[Holy Spirit in Christianity|Holy Spirit]].<ref name="Guardian"/><ref name="Moss2013"/>
==Synopsis== The book begins with "A Note to Readers" by Bill O'Reilly, which promises, "...this is not a religious book. We do not address Jesus the Messiah, only as a man who galvanized a remote area of the Roman Empire and made very powerful enemies while preaching a philosophy of peace and love." After a lengthy quotation from the conservative journalist [[Vermont C. Royster]], the introduction concludes: "But the incredible story behind the lethal struggle between good and evil has not been fully told. Until now." The first chapter begins with a [[novel]]istic description of the [[Massacre of the Innocents]] from {{bibleverse|Matthew|2:16–2:18|9}}. The remaining portion of the chapter focusses on [[Herod the Great]], the king of Judaea, the politics of his reign, the visit of the [[Biblical Magi|Magi]], and the birth of Jesus. A lengthy footnote at the end of the chapter defends the historical accuracy of the [[canonical gospels]] and their traditional attributions to [[Matthew the Apostle]], [[John Mark]], [[Luke the Evangelist]], and [[John the Apostle]].
The second chapter describes the life of the Roman general and dictator [[Julius Caesar]], his conquests, his seduction by the Egyptian [[Ptolemaic dynasty|Ptolemaic queen]] [[Cleopatra]], and [[Assassination of Julius Caesar|his eventual assassination]]. Chapter Three summarizes the aftermath of Caesar's murder, the [[Battle of Philippi]], the [[Second Triumvirate]], the [[Octavian]]'s defeat of [[Mark Antony]] and Cleopatra in the [[Battle of Actium]], and Octavian's ascension to the title of ''[[Roman emperor|emperor]]''. The fourth chapter returns to the life of Jesus, describing his worried parents looking for him after he has gone missing during a trip to [[Jerusalem]] for the [[Passover]]. It describes some of the politics of [[Judea (Roman province)|Roman Judaea]], heavily emphasizing the idea that the Jews were victims of Roman totalitarian oppression. Chapter Five describes the [[finding in the Temple]] from {{bibleverse|Luke|2:41-52|9}}, the architecture of the [[Temple in Jerusalem]], [[Nazareth]], and the government and political background of [[Galilee]].
[[File:Detail of three disciples on the far left side of the table in Leonardo da Vinci's Last Supper.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Detail of three disciples on the far left side of the table in [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s ''[[The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)|Last Supper]]'', who are shown in a [[black and white]] photograph on page 219 of ''Killing Jesus'']]
Chapter Six describes the preaching of [[John the Baptist]], the arrival of [[Pontius Pilate]] in Judaea, the [[baptism of Jesus]], and John the Baptist's arrest. Chapter Seven describes the alleged debaucheries of the Roman emperor [[Tiberius]] at [[Capri]], described by the Roman historian [[Seutonius]], accepting all of them as historical. Chapter Eight narrates the [[Cleansing of the Temple]] from {{bibleverse|John|2:13-16|9}}, Jesus's meeting with [[Nicodemus]] from {{bibleverse|John|3:1–21|9}}, and the beginning of his ministry. Chapter Nine details the calling of the apostles, the [[Sermon on the Mount]], and the [[anointing of Jesus]] from {{bibleverse||Luke|7:36-50|9}}. Following [[Sacred tradition|Catholic tradition]] rather than the gospels, the authors identify the unnamed "sinful woman" in this passage as [[Mary Magdalene]]. The chapter concludes with the [[Beheading of St John the Baptist|beheading of John the Baptist]]. Chapter Ten entails Jesus's conflicts with the [[Pharisees]] and [[Sadducees]] and concludes with a characterization of [[Judas Iscariot]].
Chapter Eleven describes Pontius Pilate's governance of Judaea and Chapter Twelve [[Triumphal entry into Jerusalem|Jesus's entry to Jerusalem]]. In Chapter Thirteen, Jesus cleanses the Temple again and [[Cursing the fig tree|curses the fig tree]]. In Chapter Fourteen, he [[Jesus at the home of Martha and Mary|goes to the house of Mary and Martha]], proclaims the [[Golden Rule]], tells the Pharisees to "[[Render unto Caesar]]", weeps over Jerusalem, and predicts his own death. Chapter Fifteen has the betrayal of Judas and Chapter Sixteen has the [[Last Supper]], the [[Agony in the Garden]], and the [[arrest of Jesus]]. Chapters Seventeen through Nineteen describe Jesus's [[Sanhedrin trial of Jesus|trial]], [[Crucifixion of Jesus|crucifixion]], and [[Burial of Jesus|burial]]. Chapter Twenty-One has the account of the [[women at the tomb]]. The "Afterward" describes [[Sources for the historicity of Jesus#Non-Christian sources|non-Christian mentions of Jesus]], the [[Apostles#Deaths|fates of the Apostles according to Catholic tradition]], as well as what happened to Tiberius, [[Caligula]], [[Caiaphas]], [[Herod Antipas]], Jerusalem, and the [[History of early Christianity|early Christian movement]].
==Publication and sales== Upon its publication, ''Killing Jesus'' debuted at #1 on ''[[The New York Times]]'' bestseller list,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2013-10-13/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html|title=Hardcover : Non-Fiction Best Sellers List|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> and was on the list for 52 weeks.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/|title=Best Sellers List|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> ''Killing Jesus'' surpassed the sales of the book ''[[Zealot: The Life and Times of Jesus of Nazareth]]'' by [[Reza Aslan]], a professor of creative writing, which had been published only a few months before.<ref name="Ehrmanlecture"/><ref name="Ehrman2016"/> Of its sales success, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote, "The most popular titles in the Washington area have a distinctly biblical glow: for the second week in a row, ''Killing Jesus'' by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard is No. 1. This is the third in their spectacularly successful assassination series, following ''Killing Kennedy'' and ''Killing Lincoln''."<ref name="Charles2013">{{cite news|last=Charles |first=Ron |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/style-blog/wp/2013/10/13/an-answer-to-publishers-prayers/ |title=An answer to publishers’ prayers |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=13 October 2013|accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> Noting the concurrent popularity of other religion-related books, the article concludes, "Publishers have long known that religion sells. Even in Washington."<ref name="Charles2013"/>
==Reception== ===Popular reviews===
In its fall books preview, ''[[USA Today]]'' called it "a suspenseful thriller."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/interactive/2764697/ |title=Fall preview: This season's 30 coolest books |website=USA Today |accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> A review of the book by Erik Wemble in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' remarked that ''Killing Jesus'' and its predecessors "may not advance the scholarship on their respective topics, but who'll take issue with millions of Americans getting a quick-read tutorial on history via O’Reilly?"<ref name="Wemble2013">{{cite news |last1=Wemble |first1=Erik |title=Bill O’Reilly and ‘Killing Jesus’: So it is! |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2013/11/11/bill-oreilly-and-killing-jesus-so-it-is/?noredirect=on |accessdate=9 June 2018 |work=The Washington Post |publisher=Nash Holdings, LLC |date=11 November 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref> Nonetheless, Wemble complained that the book's writing was full of annoying verbal [[tic]]s.<ref name="Wemble2013"/> In particular, Wemble criticizes O'Reilly's constant countdown of how much time the person he is writing about has left to live<ref name="Wemble2013"/> and his use of the phrase "so it is..." at the beginnings of sentences.<ref name="Wemble2013"/> Wemble calls the phrase a "a four-word clump of throat-clearing mumbo-jumbo"<ref name="Wemble2013"/> and states that another reviewer counted roughly sixteen or so occurrences of it in ''Killing Jesus''.<ref name="Wemble2013"/> Wemble speculates that O'Reilly may have intended this phrase as "a retroactive cliché, a little riff that would sound impressive in a book about antiquity."<ref name="Wemble2013"/>
In the book, O'Reilly and Dugard state that they are only including events that can be proven as historical fact,<ref name="Wilensky-Lanford"/><ref name="Delzell2013"/> a claim which has drawn criticism from both critics of Christianity and evangelical Christians.<ref name="Wilensky-Lanford"/><ref name="Delzell2013"/> A 2013 review by Dan Delzell for ''[[The Christian Post]]'' criticizes this statement for implying that not everything in the gospels can be proven as historical fact.<ref name="Delzell2013">{{cite web |last1=Delzell |first1=Dan |date=1 October 2013|title=Bill O'Reilly's 'Killing Jesus' Spiritualizes the Historical Christ |url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/bill-oreillys-killing-jesus-spiritualizes-the-historical-christ-105658/ |website=The Christian Post |publisher=Christian Media Corp. |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> Instead, the reviewer insists that everything in the gospel accounts is demonstrably factual and that O'Reilly's selective omission of stories found in the gospels from his book is tantamount to "cut[ting] Christ in half."<ref name="Delzell2013"/> A review by Tim Chaffey from [[Answers in Genesis]] criticizes the book for deliberately omitting several of [[Miracles of Jesus|Jesus's miracles]] and glossing over others.<ref name="Chaffey">{{cite web |last1=Chaffey |first1=Tim |date=20 November 2013|title=''Killing Jesus: A History'' by Bill O’Reilly and Martin Dugard |url=https://answersingenesis.org/reviews/books/killing-jesus-a-history-by-bill-oreilly-and-martin-dugard/ |website=''answersingenesis.com'' |publisher=Answers in Genesis |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> The same review criticized the book for its "graphic description of sexual activity"<ref name="Chaffey"/> and for portraying [[Mary Magdalene]] as a repentant prostitute, an idea that is not based on the Bible.<ref name="Chaffey"/>
In an article for ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'', [[Robert M. Price]], an atheist theologian and self-identified fan of Bill O'Reilly, labels ''Killing Jesus'' a work of complete fiction comparable to ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'',<ref name="Price">{{cite web |last1=Price |first1=Robert M. |date=4 September 2014|title=Bill O’Reilly's "Killing Jesus" is fiction: Fact-checking the Fox News' anchor's "history" of Jesus's death: A conservative theology professor unearths mistruth after mistruth in "Killing Jesus" and calls a pinhead a pinhead|url=https://www.salon.com/2014/09/04/bill_oreillys_killing_jesus_is_fiction_fact_checking_the_fox_news_anchors_history_of_jesuss_death/ |website=Salon |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> and states, "There is no sign whatsoever that the authors of "Killing Jesus" have even begun to do their homework here. In the end notes, true, we find a number of book recommendations, but it is revealing that virtually every one of the New Testament and Jesus books mentioned are the work of evangelical/fundametalist spin doctors dedicated to defending the proposition that the gospels are entirely accurate, miracles and all."<ref name="Price"/> A 2015 review of both the book and the television miniseries based on it by Brook Wilensky-Lanford in ''The Guardian'' criticizes O'Reilly for accepting Jesus's alleged miracles as potentially historical<ref name="Wilensky-Lanford">{{cite news |last1=Wilensky-Lanford |first1=Brook |title=Killing Jesus: Bill O'Reilly's film is touted as history. But facts aren't sacred to him: A Catholic self-described "traditionalist," O'Reilly can't be trusted not to confuse religious interpretation with historical fact |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/mar/29/killing-jesus-bill-oreillys-film-is-touted-as-history-but-facts-arent-sacred-to-him |accessdate=9 June 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=29 March 2015 |ref=harv}}</ref> and remarks that, although O'Reilly claims to treat his subject objectively, he "can't be trusted not to confuse religious interpretation with historical fact."<ref name="Wilensky-Lanford"/>
===Scholarly response=== [[File:DoréMaryMagdaleneRepentant.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Illustration of [[Mary Magdalene]] as a repentant prostitute by the nineteenth-century French engraver [[Gustave Doré]], which appears on page 146 of ''Killing Jesus''. [[Candida Moss]] criticizes the book for accepting this portrayal of Mary Magdalene, which is not supported by the Bible or other early Christian writings.<ref name="Moss">{{cite news |last1=Moss |first1=Candida |title=The Gospel According to Bill O’Reilly Jesus was killed because of taxes—that’s more or less the message of Bill O’s new book. Candida Moss on what else the Fox host gets wrong. |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-gospel-according-to-bill-oreilly |work=The Daily Beast |date=27 September 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref>]]
[[Candida Moss]], a professor of New Testament and early Christianity at the [[University of Notre Dame]], criticizes the book for its many historical inaccuracies in two articles written in September and October 2013 for ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' and [[CNN]] respectively.<ref name="Moss"/><ref name="Moss2013">{{cite news |last1=Moss |first1=Candida |title=Five things Bill O'Reilly flubs in ''Killing Jesus'' |url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2013/10/04/five-things-bill-oreilly-gets-wrong-in-killing-jesus/ |accessdate=8 June 2018 |work=CNN Belief Blog |publisher=Cable News Network |date=4 October 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref> Moss states that, although O'Reilly and Dugard do attempt to separate between fact and fiction, they do so inconsistently and accordingly to their previously held beliefs.<ref name="Moss"/><ref name="Moss2013"/> In her ''Daily Beast'' article, she states: "...without a method, ''Killing Jesus'' has all the critical rigor of your local church's [[Nativity play]]."<ref name="Moss"/> She notes that O'Reilly and Dugard accept late, unsubstantiated legends about the fates of the apostles after the period covered by the New Testament as historical fact.<ref name="Moss"/> They also uncritically accept the legend formalized in the fifth century by [[Pope Gregory I]] about Mary Magdalene having previously been a prostitute, which is not supported by the New Testament or any early Christian writings,<ref name="Moss"/> but ignore the statement actually recorded in the gospels that Mary Magdalene was one of the people funding Jesus's ministry.<ref name="Moss"/> They include statements from John the Baptist accusing tax collectors of overcharging people,<ref name="Moss"/> but omit all reference to Jesus's repeated injunctions to "support the poor, orphans, and widows"<ref name="Moss"/> as well as to the saying, "whoever has two coats must share with anyone who has none; and whoever has food must do likewise" ({{bibleverse|Luke|3:11|9}}).<ref name="Moss"/>
[[File:Rubens tribute money.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|''[[The Tribute Money (Rubens)|The Tribute Money]]'' (1612–1614) by [[Peter Paul Rubens]]. One of many recurring criticisms of the book is its portrayal of the [[Pharisees]] as what [[Candida Moss]] calls "self-righteous bloviators", a view which is no longer supported by mainstream scholars.<ref name="Moss2013"/><ref name="Watts2013"/>]]
In her CNN article, Moss cites the example of how they omit the line "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do", which {{bibleverse||Luke|23:34|9}} attributes to Jesus [[Sayings of Jesus on the cross|as he was being crucified]], because, as O'Reilly later said in a [[CBS]] interview, it is impossible to speak audibly while a person is being crucified.<ref name="Moss2013"/> She then points out that they chose ''not'' to omit the line "It is finished", also attributed to Jesus while he was on the cross, in {{bibleverse||John|19:30|9}}.<ref name="Moss2013"/> Moss suggests that perhaps "there [is just] something about the word 'forgiveness' that sticks in [their throats]".<ref name="Moss2013"/> She also criticizes them for taking everything written by Roman historians like [[Suetonius]] and [[Josephus]] completely at face value, as though these writers were totally unbiased.<ref name="Moss2013"/> She also particularly criticizes O'Reilly and Dugard's portrayal of the Pharisees as "self-righteous bloviators",<ref name="Moss2013"/> stating that modern Biblical scholars no longer view them this way,<ref name="Moss2013"/> and that this portrayal is, ironically, based more on the stereotype of Roman Catholics promoted by [[Protestants]] during the [[Reformation]] and [[Early Modern Period]] than on actual ancient texts.<ref name="Moss2013"/>
Moss states that ''Killing Jesus'''s description of the apostle [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] converting to "Christianity" is [[Anachronism|anachronistic]]<ref name="Moss2013"/> because, at the time, Christianity was still a Jewish sect and the word "Christian" was not even coined until near the end of the first century.<ref name="Moss2013"/> Instead, she says "the first generation of Jesus' followers lived and died as Jews."<ref name="Moss2013"/> Moss also notes O'Reilly and Dugard's unusual interpretations of various passages,<ref name="Moss2013"/> such as {{bibleverse||Luke|3:17|9}}, which O'Reilly and Dugard apparently interpret to mean that [[John the Baptist]] told the Pharisees that they will either "burn ''or'' be condemned to Hell."<ref name="Moss2013"/> She concludes: "Apart from the methodological problems, the entire book is written in the style of a novel, not a history book. We hear the thoughts of Herod as he orders the execution of the male children of Bethlehem, for instance. It's entertaining, but it's historical fan fiction, not history."<ref name="Moss2013"/>
In an article from November 2013, Joel L. Watts, author of ''Mimetic Criticism and the Gospel of Mark'', calls ''Killing Jesus'' nothing more than "an attempt at agenda-driven drivel produced for the lowest common denominator."<ref name="Watts2013">{{cite web |last1=Watts |first1=Joel L. |date=25 November 2013|title=Review of Killing Jesus: A History |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/joel-l-watts/review-of-killing-jesus_b_3984134.html |work=HuffPost |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> He adds, "I wish I had my day back."<ref name="Watts2013"/> In addition to raising many of the same accuracy concerns as Moss, Watts also criticizes the book for imputing post-[[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] ideas of [[individualism]] to ancient Galileean Jews<ref name="Watts2013"/> and for referring to the [[Sadducees]] (who believed that the [[Torah]] was the only authoritative scripture and opposed the more progressive theology promoted by the Pharisees) as "liberals".<ref name="Watts2013"/> He also criticizes a statement that the canon of the [[Hebrew Bible]] had been established "500 years" before Jesus, when, in reality, many of the books in the Hebrew Bible were not written until after that point<ref name="Watts2013"/> and the canon of the Hebrew Bible was still debated long after Jesus's death.<ref name="Watts2013"/> Watts accuses the authors of being arrogant and dismissive of the opinions of actual experts.<ref name="Watts2013"/> He determines that "they destroy context and literary construction to, and I can only assume this based on the evidence of reading the book, hide the actual message of the Gospels."<ref name="Watts2013"/>
[[File:Tea Party - Pennsylvania Avenue.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|left|Numerous scholars have criticized ''Killing Jesus'' for its anachronistic portrayal of Jesus as an advocate of "smaller government and lower taxes" similar to the supporters of the United States [[Tea Party movement]] (''protest pictured''), rather than the first-century Galilean Jew he really was.<ref name="Ehrmanlecture"/><ref name="Ehrman2016"/><ref name="Moss"/><ref name="Watts2013"/><ref name="Guardian"/>]]
A December 2013 review in ''[[The Guardian]]'' by Selina O'Grady, author of ''And Man Created God: Kings, Cults, and Conquests at the Time of Jesus'', remarks that, "Everyone creates God in their own image, so it's not surprising that [[Fox News|Fox television]]'s aggressively conservative down-home-let's-hear-it-for-the-ordinary-guy talk show host should have created a [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] son of God. Jesus, the little guy, is an enemy of the big corrupt tax-oppressing [[Roman empire]], which is itself just a version of [[Washington, D. C.|Washington]], only even more venal and sexually depraved. This Jesus is a tax-liberating rebel who incurs the wrath of the Jewish and Roman powers by threatening their joint fleecing of the people. As a member of the populist right, he is not, of course, in favour of redistribution: Bill O'Reilly's Jesus does not tell the rich to give away their money to the poor."<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|last=O'Grady|first=Selina|title=Killing Jesus: A History by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard – review: The right-wing talk show host gives us salacious gossip, gory details and a Tea Party Son of God|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/dec/18/killing-jesus-bill-oreilly-review|accessdate=17 April 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 December 2013}}</ref> The same review criticizes ''Killing Jesus'' for its "bodice-ripping treatment of history",<ref name="Guardian"/> stating that the book oversimplifies, sensationalizes, and misrepresents the historical events it purports to describe.<ref name="Guardian"/> According to O'Grady, ''Killing Jesus'' presents the Romans, Jewish elites, and Pharisees as categorically "bad" and "ordinary Jews" as "good", without any background or nuance.<ref name="Guardian"/> O'Grady also criticizes O'Reilly and Dugard for relying almost entirely on the gospels<ref name="Guardian"/> and ignoring the centuries' worth of books written by Biblical scholars about the historical Jesus.<ref name="Guardian"/>
During a Q&A session following a 2014 lecture at [[Dickinson College]] on "Jesus and the Historian", [[Bart D. Ehrman]], James A. Gray Distinguished Professor of [[religious studies]] at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], laughed at his own mention of ''Killing Jesus'', commenting "Bill O'Reilly! ''There's'' a source you trust about the historical Jesus. Hah! Aye yai yai."<ref name="Ehrmanlecture">{{cite web |last1=Ehrman |first1=Bart D. |author-link=Bart D. Ehrman| title=Jesus and the Historian (lecture) |date= 25 November 2014 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qd7Lanms-gY |time= 1:01:40 – 1:02:30|via=YouTube |publisher=Bart D. Ehrman |accessdate=8 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> In his 2016 book ''Jesus Before the Gospels'', Ehrman was less overtly hostile, merely commenting that O'Reilly is "obviously... not a New Testament scholar."<ref name="Ehrman2016">{{cite book |last1=Ehrman |first1=Bart D. |title=Jesus Before the Gospels: How the Earliest Christians Remembered, Changed, and Invented their Stories of the Savior |date=2016 |publisher=HarperOne |location=New York City, New York |isbn=978-0-06-228520-1 |page=22 |ref=harv}}</ref> In both the lecture and the book, Ehrman implicitly criticizes O'Reilly's portrayal of the historical Jesus as an advocate of "smaller government and lower taxes."<ref name="Ehrmanlecture"/><ref name="Ehrman2016"/> In the book, though, he adds, "It is easy to see how this view of Jesus might resonate with a wide swath of our population today."<ref name="Ehrman2016"/>
==Television adaptation== [[File:Haaz Sleiman 2008 cropped.jpg|thumb|[[Lebanese-American]] actor [[Haaz Sleiman]] portrayed Jesus in the [[Killing Jesus (miniseries)|''Killing Jesus'' television miniseries]].<ref name="Genzlinger"/><ref name="Maglio2015"/><ref name="Tucker2015"/>]] {{main|Killing Jesus (film)}} [[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]] picked up the television adaptation of ''Killing Jesus'', just as it had for ''[[Killing Lincoln]]'' and ''[[Killing Kennedy]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nat Geo Adapting Bill O’Reilly’s 'Killing Jesus'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/nat-geo-adapting-bill-o-430662|first=Michael|last=O'Connell|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=March 25, 2014|accessdate=March 25, 2014}}</ref> In March 2014, it was announced ''Killing Jesus'' was being adapted into a four-hour miniseries, and [[Walon Green]] has been tapped to write and executive produce the project.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2014/03/national-geographics-killing-jesus-to-expand-to-4-hours-walon-green-to-write-701056/|title=National Geographic’s ‘Killing Jesus’ To Expand To 4 Hours, Walon Green To Write| first=Nellie| last=Andreeva| website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 17, 2014|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}</ref> Also returning as executive producers are [[Ridley Scott]], [[David W. Zucker]], and Mary Lisio, who previously produced ''Killing Kennedy''. In August 2014, [[Christopher Menaul]] was attached to direct the miniseries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2014/08/christopher-menaul-to-direct-killing-jesus-mini-for-nat-geo-ridley-scott-815800/|title=Christopher Menaul To Direct 'Killing Jesus' For Nat Geo & Ridley Scott|author=The Deadline Team|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=August 7, 2014|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}</ref>
On its premiere airing, the film was watched by 3.7 million viewers, averaging a 1.0 rating among adults in the 25-54 demographic. The viewership surpassed the record previously held by ''[[Killing Kennedy (film)|Killing Kennedy]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/killing-jesus-nabs-nat-geo-785319 | title='Killing Jesus' Nabs Nat Geo Ratings Record With 3.7 Million Viewers | last=O'Connell | first=Michael | work=The Hollywood Reporter | date=March 30, 2015 | accessdate=March 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Maglio2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.thewrap.com/killing-jesus-national-geogaphic-channel-tv-ratings-killing-kennedy/ | title='Killing Jesus' Slays Nat Geo Record With 3.7 Million Viewers | last=Maglio | first=Tony | publisher=[[TheWrap]] | date=March 30, 2015 | accessdate=March 30, 2015}}</ref> A review on ''[[Yahoo TV]]'' by Ken Tucker said of the film, "Rendered without much embellishment and acted with firmly controlled vigor, ''[[Killing Jesus (film)|Killing Jesus]]'', a TV adaptation of the bestselling book by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard, is a fine retelling of the story of Jesus Christ as a historical figure. That last phrase is key. O'Reilly and his co-author sought to write only what they considered provable historical facts about Christ. Whether this has been accomplished I'll leave to historians and theologians..."<ref name="Tucker2015">{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/killing-jesus-review-bill-oreilly-114929414520.html|title='Killing Jesus': Christ in the No-Spin Zone |last=Tucker |first=Ken |date=29 March 2015 |publisher=Yahoo! |access-date=29 March 2015}}</ref> A glowing review by Hannah Goodwin for the [[Christian Broadcasting Network]] praised the film for its authentic-looking set and costumes and called it "a conversation starter".<ref name="Goodwyn">{{cite web |last1=Goodwyn |first1=Hannah |title="Killing Jesus": TV Review |url=http://www1.cbn.com/television/killing-jesus-review |website=CBN |publisher=The Christian Broadcast Network, Inc. |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> The review suggested, "Presenting Jesus' life and death from a largely historical perspective could open this religious history to wider audiences."<ref name="Goodwyn"/>
A review by Neil Genzlinger in ''[[The New York Times]]'', however, panned the film,<ref name="Genzlinger">{{cite news |last1=Genzlinger |first1=Neil |title=Review: 'Killing Jesus,' Biblical Tale Retold, Softer on Its Politics |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/27/arts/television/review-killing-jesus-biblical-tale-retold-softer-on-its-politics.html |accessdate=9 June 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=26 March 2015 |ref=harv}}</ref> declaring, "It's a costume pageant devoid both of the reverence that has made some previous film versions work and of the intrigue that might provide a secular ''[[Game of Thrones]]''-like appeal. More effort went into the jewelry and headwear than into the storytelling."<ref name="Genzlinger"/> The same review compared the miniseries unfavorably with the book, stating, "The book tried to put Jesus' story in the broader context of the politics and practices of the day, but here the account is largely pared down to the biblical rendition, with Jesus casting out a demon, preventing the stoning of a woman accused of adultery and delivering the touchstone teachings that all Christians know by heart."<ref name="Genzlinger"/>

{{italic title}} '''''Knocking Our Own Ting''''' is a pamphlet-length [[satire]] written by [[Evan X Hyde]] discussing the [[Battle of St. George's Caye]], a naval battle off the coast of [[Belize]] occurring in 1798.<ref name="XCommunication">{{cite book|last=Hyde|first=Evan X|date=1995|title=X Communication: Selected Writings|location=Belize City|publisher=Angelus Press}}</ref><ref name="Nunez">{{cite book|last1=Nunez|first1=Abdulmajeed|title=History of the Muslims in Belize|date=2010|publisher=AuthorHouse|location=Bloomington, Indiana|isbn=1452018529|page=235}}</ref> This battle has been celebrated since 1898 on September 10 as St. George's Caye Day. In the 1950s, Belizeans were beginning to question their identity and beliefs as a people, and one of the first things questioned was the "myth" of St. George's Caye. Did white master and black slave fight as equals? Or were blacks subordinates?
== Arguments == Hyde, already exposed to [[Black Power]] theory, argues that the Battle of St. George's Caye tends to divide Belizeans more than unify them. The combatants in the battle- white slavemasters and black slaves- are ancestors and forefathers of the various shades of [[Belizean Kriol people|Belizean Creole people]] and their Spanish (Mexican) opponents are forefathers of the [[Mestizo]]s. The glorifying of the slaves' efforts only further alienates Mestizo people from the development of Belize.
For Hyde, the 10th really celebrates the successful division of the Belizean people. He also questions how, after disciplining the runaway slaves from the slave revolt of 1773 harshly, the British decided to use them in fighting the hated Spanish, who had already succeeded in removing the Baymen from the settlement previously. Hyde also questions the relevancy of a holiday for Creole in a multi-racial, multi-ethnic society. He concludes that the Battle is better off celebrated for the achievements of the blacks, rather than any national pride attached to it, as long as Belize remained a colony of Great Britain (Belize became independent in 1981).
== Publishing == Benex Press issued the first edition of ''Knocking'' in 1969. It then went out of print until the publication of ''X-Communication'' by Angelus Press in 1995.

Aliyev Maarif Aghamehedi oglu is a main keeper of the museum.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Lahıc Tarix-Diyarşünaslıq Muzeyi | url=http://www.gomap.az/info/Description.aspx?idlo=30&lvo=4&pID=1484647 | publisher= | date= | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = Tarix və Diyarşünaslıq Muzeyləri | url=http://www.azerbaijans.com/content_163_az.html | publisher= | date= | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = “Azərbaycan və Norveç muzeyləri: qarşılıqlı əməkdaşlıq” (fevral – noyabr 2008) Beynəlxalq Layihə iştirakçılarının “Azərbaycan-Norveç: təəssüratlar dialoqu” adlı sərgisi | url=http://www.museumcenter.az/exhibitions_projects,16/lang,az/ | publisher= | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
==History of the museum== The museum was opened in 1985. Initially it was a part of historic-cultural natural reserve, but since 1992 it functions as an independent cultural object. Exposition of the museum consists of more than 1000 exhibits. The museum itself is located within a building which is famed as “Aghaoglu mosque” in [[Lahıc, Ismailli|Lahij]] and was built in 1914.<ref>{{Cite news | title = «Lahıc Tarix-Diyarşünaslıq Muzeyində 1250 ədəd eksponat qorunur» | url=http://www.anl.az/down/meqale/palitra/2011/sentyabr/196914.htm | publisher= | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
==Interesting facts== Kamilli Tofig Kamil oglu, a representative of the museum, participated in national trainings for trainers-specialists of museum work from the Republic of Azerbaijan by museum management using [[UNESCO]]/[[International Council of Museums|ICOM]]’s publications, held on April 20-22, 2009 in [[Baku]].

{{italic title}} [[File:Prud-hon_Mme-georges-anthony-HD.jpg|thumb|300px]] '''''Madame Georges Anthony and Her Two Sons''''' is a 1796 oil on canvas group portrait by [[Pierre-Paul Prud'hon]], now in the [[Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]], which acquired it in 1892.
Two years earlier he had fled Paris to escape the [[Thermidorian Reaction]] following Robespierre's fall. He took refuge in a family home at [[Rigny]] near [[Gray, Haute-Saône|Gray]] occupied by the postmaster Georges Anthony, his wife Louise (née Demandre) and their children. As a thank-you for their hospitality, Prud'hon painted this work and a portrait of Georges beside a horse ([[musée des Beaux-Arts de Dijon]]), both completed in 1796, the year he left their home. During the restoration of the musée des Beaux-Arts de Dijon in 2016 the paintings were briefly reunited in Lyon.
==Sources== *http://www.mba-lyon.fr/mba/sections/fr/collections-musee/peintures/oeuvres-peintures/xixe_siecle/prud-hon_mme_anthony?view_zoom=1&b_start:int=1#res_recherche

The '''Mahat chapel of Nebhepetre Mentuhotep II''' is an [[Ancient Egypt]]ian funerary chapel (Egyptian: ''mahat'') built by king [[Mentuhotep II]] (reigned c. 2046 BC – 1995 BC) at [[Abydos, Egypt|Abydos]]. The remains of the well preserved chapel were found in 2014.<ref name="luxormag">{{Cite web|url=http://luxortimesmagazine.blogspot.co.uk/2014/07/exclusive-full-story-mahat-chapel-of.html|title=Exclusive Full story: Mahat chapel of Nebhepetre Mentuhotep II discovered in Abydos by Egyptian archaeologists|website=luxortimesmagazine.blogspot.co.uk|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref>
The chapel was discovered on the 23rd April 2014, after noting a ground [[subsidence]] in front of a house in Abydos, because of illegal excavations. The Tourism and Antiquities Police was able to find the illegal diggers and the [[Ministry of State of Antiquities|Ministry of Antiquities]] was sending several archeologists for investigating the remains.<ref name=luxormag/>
The remains of the chapel are very close to the enclosure of the temple of Temple of [[Seti I]]. About 20 meter north of the funerary chapel there are the remains of a similar one, belonging to the [[New Kingdom]] king [[Ramesses I]]. The excavations have so far unearthed a chamber 2.6 wide and about 4.2 m below modern floor lever. The walls are built of fine limestone and decorated with reliefs. They show different deities and king Nebhepetre Mentuhotep II. A longer inscription states that the chapel was erected for [[Osiris]], [[Khentiamentiu]], [[Wepwawet]] and ''all gods who are in Abydos''. The inscription calls the chapel ''mahat'' and reports that a canal was dug for the chapel.<ref>Ayman Damarant, Yasir Abd el-Raziq, Ashraf Okasha, Josef Wegner, Kevin Cahail, Jennifer Wegner: ''A new temple: the mahat of Nebhepetre at Abydos'', in: ''Egyptian Archaeology'' 46 (Spring 2015), 3-7</ref>
At Abydos there are several royal chapels. This one is so far the oldest.<ref>Ayman Damarant, Yasir Abd el-Raziq, Ashraf Okasha, Josef Wegner, Kevin Cahail, Jennifer Wegner: ''A new temple: the mahat of Nebhepetre at Abydos'', in: ''Egyptian Archaeology'' 46 (Spring 2015), 3-4</ref>
